required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The State of Sexual Development in Children With Inherited Epidermolysis Bullosa
clinical_study.official_title: The State of Sexual Development in Children With Inherited Epidermolysis Bullosa

lead_sponsor.agency: National Medical Research Center for Children's Health, Russian Federation

clinical_study.source: National Medical Research Center for Children's Health, Russian Federation

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to determine the state of sexual development in patients with inherited epidermolysis bullosa; the study is planned to include boys and girls aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, junctional epidermolysis bullosa, Kindler syndrome.

detailed_description.textblock:
Determination of sexual development in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using clinical, laboratory and instrumental methods for diagnosing the condition.
Phenotyping of patients with inherited epidermolysis bullosa, taking into account their physical and sexual development, indicators of self-attitude and socialization.
Development of algorithms for individual care for patients with inherited epidermolysis bullosa, including an assessment of the psychological state at different age stages (primary school and adolescence), the volume and form of psychological and pedagogical assistance in complex rehabilitation.

primary_outcome.measure: Assessment of the state of sexual development of children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using the Tanner scale
primary_outcome.description: The endocrinologist's assessment of pubertal development in boys and girls using the Tanner Scale

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the state of functional activity of the sex glands in children with various types of inherited epidermplysis bullosa by the method of biochemical study of the level of sex hormones
primary_outcome.description: Determination of serum levels of sex hormones in patients (luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, estradiol, total testosterone).

Determination of blood levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone, cortisol, dehydroepiandrosterone-sulfate, 17-hydroxyprogesterone, prolactin, insulin, thyrotropic hormone, triiodothyronine and thyroxine.

primary_outcome.measure: Functional development and morphometric parameters of the genital glands in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa by ultrasound diagnostics
primary_outcome.description: Ultrasound examination of pelvic organs in girls and scrotal organs in boys to determine morphometric indices.

primary_outcome.measure: The state of bone age in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using X-ray examination of the hands
primary_outcome.description: Determination of bone and chronological age correspondence by radiography of the left wrist joint.

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the psychological state of children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using the Pearce-Harris scale
primary_outcome.description: Determination of the relationship between self-esteem and gender development in children with different types of hereditary epidermolysis bullosa using the Peirce-Harris scale

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the psychological state of children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using the personality drawing technique of K. Machover
primary_outcome.description: Determination of the relationship between self-esteem and gender development in children with different types of hereditary epidermolysis bullosa using the personality drawing technique of K. Machover

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the psychological state of children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using the T. Aachenbach questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: Determination of the relationship between self-esteem and gender development in children with different types of hereditary epidermolysis bullosa using the T. Aachenbach questionnaire

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the level of intellectual development in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using D. Wexler's test
primary_outcome.description: Determination of the level of intellectual development and its components (verbal and non-verbal intelligence) in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa

primary_outcome.measure: Determination of the severity of the course of the disease in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using EBDASI
primary_outcome.description: Determination of the severity of the course of the disease in children with various types of inherited epidermolysis bullosa using Epidermolysis Bullosa Disease Activity and Scarring Index (EBDASI)

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal girls with an established diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex
arm_group.description: Female patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal girls with an established diagnosis of junctional epidermolysis bullosa
arm_group.description: Female patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of junctional epidermolysis bullosa. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal girls with an established diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic
arm_group.description: Female patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal girls with an established diagnosis of Kindler syndrome
arm_group.description: Female patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of Kindler syndrome. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal boys with an established diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex
arm_group.description: Male patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal boys with an established diagnosis of junctional epidermolysis bullosa
arm_group.description: Male patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of junctional epidermolysis bullosa. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal boys with an established diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic
arm_group.description: Male patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Prepubescent and pubertal boys with an established diagnosis of Kindler epidermolysis bullosa
arm_group.description: Male patients aged 8 to 18 years with a diagnosis of Kindler syndrome. Based on the results of diagnostic methods, further division of patients into prepubertal and pubertal periods of puberty is planned.

intervention.description: Biochemical study of the level of follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, estradiol, total testosterone, prolactin, 17-hydroxyprogesterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, cortisol, insulin, thyroid-stimulating hormone, tetraiodothyronine, thyr

study_pop.textblock: Male and female patients from 8 to 18 years of age with an established diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, junctional epidermolysis bullosa, dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, Kindler syndrome.

facility.name: National Medical Research Center for Children's Health
